intro: Mentha lateovata, commonly known as late honey mint, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to parts of Europe and Asia. It belongs to the mint family, Lamiaceae, and is characterized by its square stems and opposite leaves. The plant produces small, pale blue or purple flowers that bloom in late summer. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in meadows and along stream banks. Mentha lateovata is valued for its aromatic leaves and has been used traditionally in herbal medicine.
